attributes.title: Evaluating Mechanisms of UN-Led Local Dispute Resolution: Evidence from a Survey Experiment in Mali

q1.value: Evaluating Mechanisms of UN-Led Local Dispute Resolution: Evidence from a Survey Experiment in Mali

q5.value: Kate Baldwin, Nicholas Sambanis, Molly Offer-Westort, Jiyoung Ko.

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Whereas cross-national evaluations of the UN's record have been overwhelmingly positive, local and sub-national studies have suggested a mixed record. What accounts for this macro-micro divergence of findings in the scholarly literature? More precisely, this study sets out to answer two related questions. First, does the UN reduce support for using violence as a means by which to resolve local level disputes? Second, how does the UN reduce support for using violence? In order to answer these questions, I propose three theoretical mechanism through which the UN promotes local level peace in this regard. First, the UN acts as an enforcer of local level peace, punishing and deterring individuals that use violence to resolve a dispute. Second, the UN presence increases the legitimacy of formal, domestic institutions for resolving disputes. Third, the UN diffuses a norm against violence, de-legitimizing violence as a tool for solving disputes in the process. I test these mechanisms using a survey experiment implemented in Mali, a post-conflict context in which a national peace holds but remains tenuous due to local level problems. The goal of the study is twofold. First, to assess whether the UN has any positive impact on local dispute resolution. Second, to assess how it impacts local dispute resolution. As such, the study proposes and tests three novel mechanisms.

q16.value: H1: The presence of an international enforcer reduces support for violence H2: International support of domestic, formal conflict resolution institutions reduces support for violence H3: International peacebuilders' diffusion of an aversion to violence norm reduces support for violence. H4: (a) Support for interethnic violence will be higher than support for intraethnic violence. (b) Support for interethnic violence will be higher between non-cousins than support for interethnic violence between cousins. (c) Support for interethnic violence will be higher between weak non-cousins than support for interethnic violence between strong cousins. H5: (a) The presence of an international enforcer reduces support for violence more in areas with a UN base. (b) International support of domestic, formal conflict resolution institutions reduces support for violence more in areas with a UN base. (c) International peacebuilders' diffusion of an aversion to violence norm reduces support for violence more in areas with a UN base.

q17.value: The survey experiment in the study will be implemented in two stages. First, it will be piloted in Bamako, which is an urban setting with a large UN peacekeeping component. I have randomly selected 10 neighborhoods in Mali for this pilot. Second, it will be implemented in randomly selected neighborhoods of the Segou region. The survey experiment presents respondents with a hypothetical land dispute and asks them whether they support using violence to resolve it. The randomized component randomizes the actions of the UN to address the dispute, corresponding with the three proposed mechanisms.

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: This research focuses on dehumanization – defined as the psychological act of perceiving or treating people as if they are less than fully human as a means of denying them a sense of individuality, autonomy, or dignity. Although a key psychological mechanism that impacts latent attitudes, dehumanization is an understudied topic in Political Science. The aim of this project is to study the less extreme political implication of dehumanization in a domestic context. The overarching research question that guides this research is “What impacts how people perceive the humanity of others and themselves and their policy attitudes directed at others?

q16.value: Research Questions: 1. Does exposure to dehumanizing or humanizing language used to describe a target group affect subjects’ policy stances towards that group? 2. Does exposure to humanizing or dehumanizing language affect the degree of humanity subjects ascribe to members of various groups? 3. Does exposure to dehumanizing language affect one’s perception of their own humanity? Hypotheses: 1. Exposure to dehumanizing language decreases how human subjects perceive the target group; conversely, exposure to humanizing language increases subjects’ rating of others’ humanity level. 2. Exposure to dehumanizing language increases subjects’ support of harsh policies aimed at the target group. 3. Exposure to dehumanizing language decreases subjects’ level of self-reported humanity (meta-dehumanization).

q17.value: We will employ a survey experiment for this study. Subjects will first answer a few questions meant to measure personality traits (NfA, NfC, disgust sensitivity) and a few questions about their well-being. Then, they will be exposed to either a “pure control,” or one of six real tweets by Donald Trump. One is a “baseline” that does not target any group, nor is negative or positive in sentiment. The other five either dehumanize three groups (immigrants, democrats, LGBTQ individuals), or humanize two groups (immigrants and LBGTQ individuals). Outcome measures: Using a graphical description of the “Ascent of Man,” with five silhouettes depicting the physiological and cultural evolution of humans, from early human ancestors reminiscent of modern apes, to culturally advanced modern humans, respondents will be asked to rate various groups humanity (e.g. Caucasians, African-Americans, Muslims, poor people) using a slider scale where 0 corresponds to quadrupedal primate, and 100 to modern human (modeled after Kteily et al. 2015), alongside other humanity and emotion measures. Then subjects will be asked to rate their level of agreement with a battery of policy questions related to the target group on a 5-point Likert scale. We will conduct multiple regression and cluster analysis to estimate treatment effects on dehumanizing and policy attitudes.

attributes.title: Inequality, Nationalism, and Political Demands: A Survey-Experiment in China

q1.value: Inequality, Nationalism, and Political Demands: A Survey-Experiment in China

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: This research builds on the findings that the Chinese population is aware of inequality and does view it as a large problem. However, the public's associated political demands are unknown. Additionally, research shows that Chinese nationalism is important, changing over time (Gries 2004), and extremely high (Tang and Darr 2012). While it is known that nationalism has important international consequences (Zhao 2013, Weiss 2013, Weiss 2014), and that the interplay between nationalism and regime legitimacy is extremely important (Tang and Darr 2012, Zhao 2013), there is very little research on the behavioral foundations of inequality or nationalism in China, and little understanding of how these factors effect regime legitimacy.

q16.value: Parenthetical references in the hypotheses below - e.g. (1b), (2a), etc. connect the hypotheses to specific vignettes in the survey. H1a: Priming respondents with information about inequality being high (1b) leads to a greater emphasis on fundamental problems with the political system, specifically (i) rooting out central government corruption and (ii) broadening the practice of elections, relative to a control in which inequality is not primed (1c). H1b: Priming respondents with information about inequality being high (1b) leads to a greater emphasis on fundamental problems with the political system, specifically (i) rooting out central government corruption and (ii) broadening the practice of elections, relative to a control in which other negative information about regime performance, in the form of slow economic growth, is provided (1a). H2: Priming respondents with a vignette related to the ruling on the South China Sea and the CCP's response (2a) leads to a reduction in the effect of emphasis on fundamental problems with the political system, specifically (i) rooting out central government corruption and (ii) broadening the practice of elections, relative to a control in which respondents are provided with either of two other international informational primes (2bii and 2biii). H3: Priming respondents with a vignette related to the ruling on the South China Sea and the CCP's response (2a) leads to a reduction in the effect of slow economic performance (1a) on fundamental problems with the political system, specifically (i) rooting out central government corruption and (ii) broadening the practice of elections, relative to the population that receives this same prime of slow economic growth (1a) and purely informational primes (2bii and 2biii).

q17.value: DVs are measured with conjoint experiment with multiple treatment groups.

q27.value: Online survey hosted on Qualtrics platform.

attributes.title: Communicating Ingroup Criticism during Conflict: An Experiment in Israel

q1.value: Communicating Ingroup Criticism during Conflict: An Experiment in Israel

q9.value: I have completed a single focus group and have access to that data; however, I have not analyzed that data. I still have approximately 30 focus groups left to complete.

q15.value: In situations of conflict, ingroup criticism - criticism that members of a given social group direct towards their fellow ingroup members or towards the group itself - can help prevent negative intergroup outcomes. But one factor that could determine the effectiveness of ingroup criticism is the receptiveness of others. This study tests other ingroup members’ receptiveness to two frames for criticism: A moralistic frame, which justifies the criticism by arguing that the criticized ingroup behavior is immoral, and a group-interested frame, which argues that the criticized behavior is harmful to the group’s interests. These frames are tested in an experiment involving participants in several dozen focus groups, each with 4–6 Jewish Israeli participants, in Haifa, Israel. The topic of discussion for these focus groups centered on the killing of a neutralized Palestinian attacker by an Israeli soldier in March, 2016, and specifically addressed whether or not the soldier’s actions should have been condemned by prominent Israeli political and military leaders as it was. The experimental treatment was delivered through a confederate who participated in these groups as if he were also a research subject. In a third of the groups, the confederate took a neutral position; in the other two-thirds, he argued in favor of condemnation from either a moralistic or group-interested frame. To measure the effect of these frames, after the focus group, participants provided measures of their willingness to engage in ingroup criticism themselves, their approval of criticism coming from other ingroup members, and their willingness to compromise with the outgroup (Palestinians). It is hypothesized that results from this experiment will show that a moralistic frame incurs a backlash among other ingroup members, making them less likely to express or approve criticism and less willing to compromise with the outgroup, whereas the group-interested frame increases such willingness.

q16.value: Most of the quantities of interest fall into three groups in this study: (1) willingness to engage in ingroup criticism, (2) approval of criticism coming from other ingroup members, and (3) willingness to compromise with the outgroup (Palestinians). 1. Willingness to engage in ingroup criticism: - An index of responses to four statements about the behavior of the soldier (agree/disagree, 1-7 scale). - Coded participant statement in a letter asked to write (supportive/condemning of soldier, 1-5 scale). - Average of coded participant statements in focus group (supportive/condemning of soldier, 1-5 scale). 2. Approval of criticism coming from other ingroup members: - An index of responses to two statements about leaders' condemnation of soldier (agree/disagree, 1-7 scale). - Coded participant statement in a letter asked to write (supportive/condemning of leaders, 1-5 scale). - Responses to statements about how convincing the confederate was and how much he contributed to the conversation (agree/disagree, 1-7 scale, will likely analyze these two questions individually but may combine into an index if answers to these questions follow similar patterns). - An index of responses to eleven statements about the importance of silencing others (agree/disagree, 1-7 scale). 3. Willingness to compromise with the outgroup (Palestinians): - Indices of responses to seven statements about willingness to compromise over a variety of issues in the Israeli-Palestinian conflict (oppose/support, 1-5 scale, two separate indices, one with the first five questions, the other with the final two). "Moralistic" treatment, compared to control: less willingness to engage in ingroup criticism, lower approval of criticism from others, and less willingness to compromise with Palestinians. "Group-interested" treatment, compared to control: more willingness to engage in ingroup criticism, more approval of criticism from others, and more willingness to compromise with Palestinians. In addition to the questions outlined above, I also look at how subjects rate the convincingness of/contribution of all group members, as well as a six-item question evaluating the anxiety level of participants after participating in the focus group.

q17.value: These hypotheses will be tested using linear regression. Because of the small sample size, I will control for some important covariates that are likely to have an effect on the outcome, aside from a regression without such covariates. Importantly, I will not include any such covariates to control for imbalances between treatment and control groups. Covariates to control for when looking at outcomes measuring willingness to engage in ingroup criticism: An index of responses to four statements measuring subjects' level of identification as Jewish and political ideology. Covariates to control for when looking at outcomes measuring approval of criticism coming from other ingroup members: An index of responses to four statements measuring subjects' level of identification as Jewish and political ideology. Covariates to control for when looking at outcomes measuring willingness to compromise with the outgroup (Palestinians): An index of responses to four statements measuring subjects' level of identification as Jewish, political ideology, and a dichotomous variable for whether or not the subject has been exposed to violence related to the conflict (as measured by responses to three questions). Because randomization occurred at the focus group level for this study, I will conduct my analysis using clustered standard errors.

attributes.title: Understanding Support for Sectarian Politics: Evidence from Survey Experiments in Lebanon

q1.value: Understanding Support for Sectarian Politics: Evidence from Survey Experiments in Lebanon

q2.value: Laura Paler | Sami Atallah | Leslie Marshall

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: Ethnic or sectarian politics dominate in many developing countries. Despite the prevalence of ethnic (sectarian) politics, a large political economy literature has argued that more ethnically diverse societies have lower levels of public goods provision, higher levels of clientelism, and weaker accountability. The adverse aspects of ethnic politics raise two questions central to a growing body of literature focused on understanding how to increase support for programmatic politics in countries dominated by ethnic or clientelist politics. To what extent do citizens support the ethnic status quo (meaning the institutionalization of politics along ethnic lines) and to what extent would they prefer an alternative basis of political organization, particularly one which gave primacy to programmatic, issue-based politics? Second, is it possible to reduce support for ethnic politics and increase support for an alternative?

q16.value: We use a set of survey experiments to explore two questions: (1) To what extent do citizens in Lebanon support sectarianism in politics, and (2) Is it possible to reduce support for sectarian politics and increase support for programmatic politics? To address the first question we use allocation experiments and public/private variations for a petition and Facebook group membership to measure preference falsification with respect to sectarianism. To study the second question, we use information treatments on economic inequality and the cross-cutting nature of the economic cleavage in Lebanon to see if increasing awareness of economic class interests reduces support for sectarian politics.

q17.value: The pre-analysis plan states 26 hypotheses that will be tested. The first set of hypotheses are about whether private preferences will diverge from public preferences when those preferences are made known to political elites and peers. We also hypothesize that the degree of preference falsification will vary depending on the nature of private preferences and the degree to which individuals are vulnerable to social or elite sanctioning for making their true preferences public. The second set of hypotheses focuses on the effects of providing information on economic inequality and the cross-cutting nature of an economic cleavage. We will also look at mechanisms and heterogeneous effects based on identity attachment, sectarian and economic status, and key demographic characteristics (among some others).

The second set of hypotheses focuses on the effects of providing information on economic inequality and the cross-cutting nature of an economic cleavage. We will also look at mechanisms and heterogeneous effects based on identity attachment, sectarian and economic status, and key demographic characteristics (among some others).

attributes.title: Measuring UK Attitudes towards Public Spending: Validation of Predictions from a Multivariate Tax Summary Experiment

q1.value: Measuring UK Attitudes towards Public Spending: Validation of Predictions from a Multivariate Tax Summary Experiment

q2.value: Lucy Barnes | Jack Blumenau | Benjamin Lauderdale

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: In late 2018 we fielded a continuous treatment, multivariate choice experiment assessing UK public preferences over budgeting trade-offs. We then used a structural model to translate these choices into estimates of the average public preferences for spending in 14 budget areas and the overall tax level. These estimates are not in the domain directly tested by the experiment, and so the purpose of this validation study is to assess whether this profile of spending and tax levels is in fact preferred to the status quo, and whether it is preferred by the popular margin that our modelling predicts. This validation study therefore consists of a single non-experimental survey question. We are pre-registering our expectations derived from the structural model of responses to the previous experiment, the survey question, our analysis plan for the primary validation exercise, and our commitment to report the results of the validation along with the original experiment.

q16.value: The estimates of our structural model imply that 72.6% (SE: 2.7%, 95% interval: 68.0-78.7%) of the UK public will prefer the proposed profile of spending to the status quo. Thus, the quantity of interest for our primary validation exercise is the proportion of (population weighted) respondents who prefer the proposal to the status quo, and how much it deviates from this prediction. As a secondary validation exercise, we will examine whether the demographic variation in responses regarding this proposal match the demographic variation implied by our structural model, however we are not pre-registering specific expectations regarding this demographic structure or how we will carry out this analysis.

q17.value: The details of the survey prompt are included in our pre-analysis plan. Because respondents will have the option of giving “Not sure” responses, our pre-analysis plan also states a specific strategy for estimating the quantity of interest in the presence of these responses, in a way that is maximally comparable to our analysis of the original experiment. Our pre-analysis plan states the ranges of results that we would consider to be successful validation, as well as the most likely reasons that we can identify why the validation might fail.

q19.value: 3000 respondents (the exact number is out of our control, YouGov typically provides somewhat more than the number paid for)

q21.value: The standard error for estimating a proportion of 0.726 from a sample of 3000 is 0.008. While the “Not sure” responses complicate our analysis slightly from this benchmark, the nature of our validation exercise and the imprecision of the 0.726 target poin

q23.value: The original experiment received ethics committee approval and we have received approval for an amendment to do this validation study.

q27.value: The survey is being administered by YouGov UK

registration_responses.q1: Measuring UK Attitudes towards Public Spending: Validation of Predictions from a Multivariate Tax Summary Experiment
registration_responses.q2: Lucy Barnes | Jack Blumenau | Benjamin Lauderdale
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to realization of outcomes
registration_responses.q15: In late 2018 we fielded a continuous treatment, multivariate choice experiment assessing UK public preferences over budgeting trade-offs. We then used a structural model to translate these choices into estimates of the average public preferences for spending in 14 budget areas and the overall tax level. These estimates are not in the domain directly tested by the experiment, and so the purpose of this validation study is to assess whether this profile of spending and tax levels is in fact preferred to the status quo, and whether it is preferred by the popular margin that our modelling predicts. This validation study therefore consists of a single non-experimental survey question. We are pre-registering our expectations derived from the structural model of responses to the previous experiment, the survey question, our analysis plan for the primary validation exercise, and our commitment to report the results of the validation along with the original experiment.
registration_responses.q16: The estimates of our structural model imply that 72.6% (SE: 2.7%, 95% interval: 68.0-78.7%) of the UK public will prefer the proposed profile of spending to the status quo. Thus, the quantity of interest for our primary validation exercise is the proportion of (population weighted) respondents who prefer the proposal to the status quo, and how much it deviates from this prediction. As a secondary validation exercise, we will examine whether the demographic variation in responses regarding this proposal match the demographic variation implied by our structural model, however we are not pre-registering specific expectations regarding this demographic structure or how we will carry out this analysis.
registration_responses.q17: The details of the survey prompt are included in our pre-analysis plan. Because respondents will have the option of giving “Not sure” responses, our pre-analysis plan also states a specific strategy for estimating the quantity of interest in the presence of these responses, in a way that is maximally comparable to our analysis of the original experiment. Our pre-analysis plan states the ranges of results that we would consider to be successful validation, as well as the most likely reasons that we can identify why the validation might fail.
registration_responses.q19: 3000 respondents (the exact number is out of our control, YouGov typically provides somewhat more than the number paid for)
registration_responses.q21: The standard error for estimating a proportion of 0.726 from a sample of 3000 is 0.008. While the “Not sure” responses complicate our analysis slightly from this benchmark, the nature of our validation exercise and the imprecision of the 0.726 target poin
registration_responses.q23: The original experiment received ethics committee approval and we have received approval for an amendment to do this validation study.
registration_responses.q27: The survey is being administered by YouGov UK

attributes.title: The role of motive attribution in the perpetuation of intergroup conflict

q1.value: The role of motive attribution in the perpetuation of intergroup conflict

q2.value: Daphna Canetti | Joshua Gubler | Eran Zaidese | Thomas Zeitzoff

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: In previous research, we have each explored various factors that perpetuate violent group conflict. In this research, we focus on one such factor that we hypothesize motivates the continuation of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict: one side's perceptions of the "true motives" of the other. We will begin by focusing on Israeli perceptions of the motives of Palestinians, intending to expand the scope of the research to Palestinians and other groups after completion of this first experiment. A recent survey we completed in Israel suggests that those who feel that the "true motives" (as opposed to the stated motives) of Palestinians who engage in violence are deep-seated Anti-Jewish sentiment--as opposed to more proximate motives like increased human rights, land ownership, and jobs--are much more likely to support increased violence towards Palestinians generally as compared to those who think the Palestinians are motivated by more proximate concerns like those just listed. To test these observational findings, we propose a survey experiment that will randomly assign individuals to news articles presenting research evidence that suggests these differing motives: one article will present evidence that Palestinians are motivated by anti-Jewish concerns, and the other that they are motivated by lack of political, economic and social opportunities. We will also include a placebo article as a control condition. Respondents will then answer a series of questions about support for violence against Palestinians. A companion study in the US will test whether these factors generalize, looking at the effect of perceived motivation for individuals joining/participating in ISIS on support for different counter-terror tactics and foreign policy preferences. As part of this study, respondents will be shown news articles presenting research evidence that suggests different motives for joining/participating in ISIS: one article will present evidence that participants are motivated by a radical anti-Western/anti-Islamic ideology, and the other that they are motivated by lack of political, economic and social opportunities. A third group will be given the same placebo treatment as in the Israel study. Following this, we will gauge support for potential anti-ISIS measures, and more general foreign policy preferences towards the Middle East.

q16.value: The survey experiments in Israel and America are designed to be virtually identical, differing only in question wording to reflect the different contexts, and in the outgroups on which they focus (in the Israel case, it is Palestinians involved in stabbing attacks; in the American case, it is those fighting for ISIS). Both surveys begin by measuring initial perceptions towards the outgroup and include measures to explore heterogeneous treatment effects (like degree of militarism, etc.). Both then randomly assign participants to one of three conditions: a placebo condition (article about social media), a condition presenting participants with an article in which an expert says the motives of the outgroup are hatred (hatred article), and a condition where they are presented with an article in which the expert claims the motives are lack of political or economic opportunities (lack of opportunity article). We will then measure their level of support for violent measures against the outgroup of various types.

q17.value: We will test these hypotheses via a survey experiment in both Israel and the US, examining how manipulating perceptions of terrorist motivation influence support for different policies. Our main research question is how does differential perceptions of motivation (lack of opportunity vs. hatred) influence support for counter-terror policies--and whether ideology, psychological aggression, and terrorism-related stress/exposure moderate this relationship.

q24.value: Canetti (University of Haifa): #199/16 ; Gubler (BYU): FWA with American U. ; Zeitzoff (American U.): #2016-301

q25.value: Canetti (University of Haifa): 1 June 2016 ; Gubler (BYU): 29 June 2016 ; Zeitzoff (American U.): 24 May 2016

q27.value: Third Party: The Midgam Project, an online survey panel in Israel, will handle the sampling, random assignment, and data collection for our sample there. Amazon’s Mechanical Turk will handle sampling and data collection for the American portion of the su

attributes.title: Post Hurricane Voting Information via SMS

q1.value: Post Hurricane Voting Information via SMS

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: This field experiment tests whether SMS messages (i.e. text messages) can be used to provide information about voting to encourage participation in the wake of major natural disasters. In the wake of natural disasters, election administration is disrupted and voting is likely to become a lower priority. At the same time, people affected by natural disasters should not be disenfranchised on top of other impacts from the disaster – especially as they are usually in significant need of assistance from government agencies. Past research has demonstrated that increasing “search costs” to find voting locations and “transportation costs” to reach voting locations decreases turnout (Brady and McNulty 2011). Research on the administration of the 2012 election in the wake of Hurricane Sandy indicates that steps by local election officials to reduce these costs, such as using the same voting locations, may bolster turnout in affected areas (Stein 2015). This research builds on these concepts by seeking to deliver information about voting to people in the impacted areas using a method of communication (SMS) likely to reach individuals despite disruptions of natural disasters. The experiment is conducted during the 2018 election in counties in Florida and Georgia declared federal disaster areas in the wake of Hurricane Michael and in counties in North Carolina declared federal disaster areas in the wake of Hurricane Florence. The experiment is conducted among people of color in these areas based on historical patterns of low participation. The treatment takes advantage of the availability of early in-person voting in each of the three states. The first two SMS messages (scheduled for October 25 and October 30) note that public records indicate whether the individual has cast a ballot yet, and provides information on early voting locations and hours to encourage this form of voting in the wake of the hurricane. The mention of public records about voting was intended to make voters aware their voting behavior was being monitored to elicit social pressure (Green and Gerber 2015). Early voting allows voters to cast a ballot at any location within their county of registration, an especially valuable convenience in the wake of a hurricane. Early voting also allows voters to select when to vote, again a convenience likely to be heightened in the wake of a hurricane. The third and final message (scheduled for November 4) again noted that a ballot had not yet been cast according to public records and provided information on how to find up-to-date Election Day polling place locations.

attributes.title: Voting and Representation After Shelby: Did pre-clearance matter?

q1.value: Voting and Representation After Shelby: Did pre-clearance matter?

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: The passage of the Voting Rights Act in 1965 had an immediate effect on voter registration, turnout, and representation, particularly in southern states that had been systematically disenfranchising African-Americans (Schuit and Rogowski, 2017). Five decades later, the Supreme Court, in the Shelby County v. Holder decision, dramatically changed the voting rights landscape by invalidating Section 4 of the VRA. This effectively ended the “pre-clearance” process, under which localities with a history of discrimination were required to get Justice Department approval of changes to their election procedures. The majority decision suggested that, while the VRA had once been useful, such strict monitoring was no longer necessary. Defenders of the VRA and of pre-clearance argued that the law continued to provide important protections to minority voters, and that removing this portion could have catastrophic effects (Wilson, 2015; Herron and Smith, 2016). Since the 2013 decision, several federal elections have taken place. These do not provide enough data to test long-run theories about shifts in the electorate or slow-moving policy changes, but they do merit a simple examination of whether there have been clear shifts in minority voting registration and turnout, as well as in legislative representation, since the decision.

q16.value: We want to know whether the pre-clearance portion of the Voting Rights Act still mattered for minority voting and representation; that is, did removing pre-clearance change the electoral landscape for minority voters? We focus on outcome measures that capture the main goals of the VRA as we understand them: ensuring the opportunity to register and vote, especially for groups that have historically faced discrimination, and improving meaningful representation in government. This means that we look for changes in the following outcomes: Black and Hispanic voter turnout and registration rates, proportion of representatives (in Congress/state legislature) that are Black/Hispanic, and Congressional representatives’ voting records on civil rights. We describe the data sources for each of these outcome measures in the pre-analysis plan; we have not yet collected or purchased any of this data and will do so after filing this pre-registration.

q17.value: The pre-analysis plan describes two possible difference-in-differences designs; our decision about which is best suited to the data will depend on an analysis of pre-treatment time trends (so we will choose which path to take after seeing the data). We will then present the alternative approach in an appendix, along with our rationale for the choice we make. For each, the basic intuition is that we want to compare changes in our outcomes of interest (from before the Shelby decision to after) in places that were and were not affected by the decision. The simplest difference-in-differences approach would simply compare our outcome measures (for example, Black voter turnout rates) across pre- and post-Shelby elections, in places that were and were not previously covered by pre-clearance. The idea here is that if pre-clearance had mattered for electoral behavior, we should see formerly-covered places changing a lot after the Shelby decision (relative to ``untreated” places that had not been subject to pre-clearance anyway). However, if we worry that covered and non-covered jurisdictions would not have had parallel trends on our outcome measures even in the absence of the court decision, we might instead use a triple-differences approach that relies on a within-jurisdiction comparison to white voter outcomes. Again focusing on the example of voter turnout, this approach would mean that we would look at the over-time change in the Black-White or Hispanic-White turnout gap in covered and uncovered counties (rather than just Black turnout levels).
